SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: John Bethune Stewart
2. Your address: [illegible]
3. Date: January 13th, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Botmilk, near Leslie, Fife, Scotland on 26th Sept 1869
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   John Stewart Ploughman
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Spring of 1894 came by team from Oak Lake man
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   On 5th of June left by ox team took a week on the road or rather trail there were no roads
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   After nearly 12 yrs working on 5 different farms and
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Knowing Geo. Munro and his son came to Canada in 92 I joined him and helped him to get started and in 94 he got his family out wife 3 daughters and 2 sons and J. Munro came with them
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information)?
    Peter Fleming (Dunder) Emigration agent came to Milnathort and I had a talk with him so booked on the Lake Superior from Liverpool
    24th Mar 1894 and had a 1/2 days sail

11. We came in 1894 and had a 13 days sail
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Father & mother, sister and brother and John Messham came out in 1900.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   A jolly party on board ship and Raff Rawlinson was the life of the party.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way,
   meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement,
   etc.)
   The boys at Oak Lake escorted me to the Unique House in grand style.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   On E. Munro's homestead & 1/2 2 1/4 W 1/2 nd and did a little breaking and got sod buildings up.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   On N.W. 3 6.3. K. in May 1885.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   The winters we stayed together and of course if I was full 17-98 loaded coal at Roche Perce station
   in the car from Mat Knight's mine 2 tons to the load
   5 loads a day at 30¢ a ton.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   On farms / anything that turned up in 1900
   hauled bridge timbers from Arcola and from moosomin in 1901 and did a lot of Breaking
   around from 20 acres to 100 in some cases.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Father, mother, sister, and brother came out in 1900.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)? John Macintosh came out in 1900.

13. What means of transportation did you use? A jolly hearty ox team and Raff Rawlinson.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the road, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

The boys at Oak Lake escorted me to the Unique House in grand style.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On & around homestead & ½. 2½ 4½ 6½ 8½ and did a little breaking and got good buildings.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On Nov. 36, 3. 4. in May.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

The winters we stayed together and of course if I was full 97 98 loaded coal at Roche Perce Station in the fall from Mat Knight's mine 2 tons to the load.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

On farms, farming, farm work, and horses.

Hauled bridge timbers from Assiniboia and harvested corn in 1901 and did a lot of breaking around from 20 acres to 100 in some cases.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Often enough to keep in touch, Alameda, N.W.T., was our P.O. and no roads.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   1st Jan 1902 at the home of her sister, N.W.T.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Settled here for a time. Cousins moved in New Westminster B.C. and some others as I sent a letter to the People's Journal in Dundee and the authorities must have made use of it for I got a lot of correspondence.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   My 2nd brother and his wife and family came out in 1912. They both passed away but their families are still here, and I messiah relatives are still around. Morrison boys came here but went on to Alberta. Laurie family came about this time also.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   The starting of roads in this part where I spent a few summers in Jupio 2-3 as road foreman.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   As you know travel on foot to Oxbow and Alameda until I got a sod house built in 1896 when we had a minister come from Alameda though Rev. J.R. Scott from Oxbow was the principal. Then we got a school in 1900 Munro School #544. Frohisher Village was started 1900.
3.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Often enough to keep in touch. Alameda, Calif., was our P.O. and we wrote.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date.

Married 1912 at the home of the Reverend Mr. Smith.

21. Did either Elizabeth or John come to Salt Lake City to settle? (Listed here for a time.)

Neither came for a time. We came to Salt Lake City in 1886.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

My brother and his wife and family came out in 1912. They both passed away but their families are still here and my children still live here but went on to around 2 generations. My family came also. This time also.

23. In what particular experiences do you feel you have been blessed?

The starting of Alameda in this part where I lived a few summers in June 2-3, 40 acres.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

As you know, we traveled on foot to Alameda and Alameda until we got a card house built in 1896 when we had a minister come from Alameda through Rev. J.R. Scott from Ashby was the municipal. Then we got a school in 1905.

Munro School #544

Foster's Village was started 1900
25. When was the first car used in the community?  
   never owned a car

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?  
   Alameda 7 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)  
   until Frohisher could handle it

29. How often did you shop in the early days?  
   not any oftener than necessary when you take a box of crackers and a lot of tea for the weeks supply of butter and eggs

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?  
   When the cars started to come in

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?  
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?  
   Alameda Telephone Co in which I put $25.00

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?  
   Yes. By what I written you can pretty well judge

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

There are none of the old pioneers left on the homestead today, a very few of the sons are still carrying on.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

None I know came back.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

22 yrs ago was a W.F.C. member for Dist. 1 and about 1915 a life member about that time we started a coop to handle twine and other things but the younger folks let it pass out but have an oil business larger than ever.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

About 1912 3 churches decided to join and built a nice church in 1913 I was sunday school sup't about that time and tried to get Lutherians to join in but nothing doing and they are stronger than now.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Munro school was named after Geo Munro of course Mayflower was built the same fall by the same builders but I have no idea how it got its name Munro gave them land so they could have it "4 & 5 mile

Today a very few of the sons are still carrying on.

Many know some brewhouse.

Try the same builder but I have no idea how it got its name. Henry gave them lonely so they could have it.
